title: What's at stake in Michigan State vs. Ohio State? 'It's a playoff game'
text:
CLOSE SportsPulse: Paul Myerberg prognosticates that Michigan and Auburn could join the national conversation with bigs wins this weekend. USA TODAY

EAST LANSING, Mich. — Twenty-eight players on Michigan State's football roster hail from Ohio, making Saturday's showdown at Ohio State a bit more meaningful than most.

Those 28 players, which include 10 likely starters, will take on the No. 5 Buckeyes at Ohio Stadium, and only one of them, punter Jake Hartbarger, has played in a victory over the Buckeyes — Michigan State's 17-14 upset win in 2015 that propelled them to the College Football Playoff.

Since then, there has been two close losses in East Lansing and a 48-3 Ohio State walloping in 2017 in Columbus.

But for the Ohioans on the team, many of whom were not recruited heavily by Ohio State, this chance Saturday night could erase the recent bad memories.

Michigan State linebacker Joe Bachie (35) celebrates a tackle against Indiana during the second half at Spartan Stadium on Sept. 28, 2019. (Photo: Junfu Han, Detroit Free Press)

“Being an Ohio guy, it means a little something extra to me,” said senior safety David Dowell, a North Ridgeville native. “I prepare the same regardless of the opponent… Sometimes in those big games you can get all hyped up and you forget about your assignment, so it’s all about having that balance.”

BOLD PREDICTIONS: What unexpected result to watch for Saturday

STAFF PICKS: Our experts predict Auburn-Florida and the rest of Week 6

BIG GAMES: Five Week 6 matchups with College Football Playoff impact

For Michigan State coach Mark Dantonio, who grew up in Zanesville and won a national championship in 2002 as Ohio State’s defensive coordinator, he focused less on the personal nature of the game and more on the stakes of it.

“I really think that any time you're in a conference, you're trying to become the best in your conference, so you've got to measure up. Ohio State has been a dominant program in this conference,” he said. “You've got to be able to measure up to win your share there or if you want to be Big Ten champion. The two times we've won and beat Ohio State, we've become the Big Ten champion.”

Since 2011, when the Big Ten added Nebraska and switched to a divisional format, Michigan State and Ohio State have combined for seven out of the 16 spots in the Big Ten championship game.

“It’s a playoff game,” senior linebacker Joe Bachie, from Brook Park, Ohio, said. “You want to be the best, you want to go to the Big Ten championship, this is the game you’ve gotta win.”

Bachie focused on the environment — the game is a “Blackout” with Ohio State wearing black alternate jerseys and the expected 104,944 fans clad in the same color.

It is not a hospitable environment for visitors, especially those hailing from the Mitten State. Buckeyes fans are known to sing a song about how they “don’t give a damn for the whole state of Michigan” when facing off against Michigan State or Michigan.

“It’s special obviously to go back down there,” Bachie said. “I’ll be grateful to play on a stage like this. To play on ABC, 7:30 at night, in Columbus, millions of people watching. Coming back home, this is the last chance to play them, the last chance I get to beat them, and really a lot of the guys from Ohio have the same mindset. This is going to be a special week for a bunch of us.”

The road to the Big Ten championship game in Indianapolis goes through Columbus, as Mark Dantonio said multiple times this week.

“This means everything,” senior defensive tackle Raequan Williams said.
description: Michigan State features 28 players from Ohio, which makes for a key story line when the Spartans visit Ohio State in 'playoff game' between the teams.
authors: Special To The Detroit Free Press
